question.title: Unable to locate an element with the xpath expression //span[@class='windowTitle']
question.body:
OK I cannot figure out this error. We are running an IE test (testng with selenium) (which opens Edge) on a Jenkins machine. I keep getting this error "Unable to locate an element with the xpath expression //span[@class='windowTitle']" (see HTML below). The Jenkins logfile has the source HMTL and when I inspect and do a search for "//span[@class='windowTitle']" it finds it fine. When we get a Jenkins error I always download to Eclipse and run locally on my machine. When I do that it finds the xpath with no problems. Xpaths prior to this statement are also found.

Usually with "Object Errors" it can be a driver/browser mismatch. I don't have direct access to the Jenkins machine but they told me it is Edge Version 142.0.3595.53 and we just updated (to try to fis the problem which didn't work) the driver to 142.0.3595.80.

HTML code is (partial)

 <span class="windowNoMargin">
   <span class="windowTitle">Search Facility</span>
   <span class = 'buttonarea'>...</span>
 </span>

As I say those object errors are usually a result of mismatched browser/driver but these should be compatible.

The code searching for the XPATH:

do {
    System.out.println("Searching for Search Input Page Header");
} while (!timer.done() && !SeleniumTools.waitForWebElementVisible(driver, By.xpath(gei.getProperty(
                "searchPage_Title")), DELAY));

waitForWebElementVisible() does a WebDriverWait for the expected condition. The property "searchPage_Title" is searchPage_Title=//span[@class='windowTitle']

I am not sure what else to try. Again to reiterate it works find when I run it locally from my machine. My Edge is 142.0.3595.80 and Edge Driver is 142.0.3595.76. I don't believe the IEDriverServer has changed in a long time. I did a query for the latest version 4.14.0.0.

I would like to include more HTML code but am worried about company proprietary information.

question_comments.body: So I did the web driver wait, changed the xpath to use css values.  It reduced the number of error occurrences but they still occur.  There were two separate ones. Another one I was having problems with had text so I had to do a driver.findBys() and iterate through each, doing a getText(), until I found the one I wanted.
first thing I'd do is use a standard webdriverwait... no reason to re-write the polling there.

I would love to show more code but am worried about company proprietary stuff.  As for the gei.getProperty("searchPage_Title") it evaluates to "//span[@class='windowTitle']" and I replaced the get property statement with it directly.  As for waitForWebElementVisible() I replaced that with a sleep for 60 seconds and then a driver.findElement(By.xpath("//span[@class='windowTitle']"))‌​; and had the same problem.  Yes, I know doing a findElements won't return an error but if the element is not there after 60 seconds it won't be.

Namespaces: I see what you mean.  Yes, some times I have used name spaces to find locations. This is mostly when we send a SOAP request and get back a response.  I have not seen it on regular web page xml
Yes, no I-Frame.  To be sure I did a switchToDefaultContent() but examining the HTML it is not in one.

But the fact that you're not familiar with XML namespaces makes this a very likely cause of the problem. Basically if the file contains an attribute of the form xmlns="http://something/", then you need to change your XPath (search the site for XPath default namespace).

What Michael and others are saying is that HTML documents often (usually?) have elements with XML namespaces. In those HTML documents, there is no element named just scan. Try replacing searchPage_Title=//span[@class='windowTitle'] with searchPage_Title=//*[local-name()='span'][@class='windowTitl‌​e'].
@Tony, I think Michael meant XML namespace declarations in the [X]HTML input. That has nothing to do with Java packages.
Have you checked to make sure that this element is not inside an IFRAME or similar?
Edit your question and add these: 1. the code for waitForWebElementVisible(), 2. the result of By.xpath(gei.getProperty("searchPage_Title")), and 3. the full error stack. We need more info.
Could it be that the xpath is not yet present so when it checks to see whether it is visible the element is still null because it had not yet been found>

I did look but as I suspected In Java, the concept of a namespace is implemented using packages. The declaration is made using the package keyword at the very beginning of a Java source file.   The files all have correct packages.  Eclipse takes care of that.
Have you checked the file for namespace declarations?
